indicators.justification:
Emissions data reported to the UNFCCC via Cambodia's National Communications are available at a government website, but they can only be extracted/downloaded with prior permission from the government agency. They are also outdated. Thus there are no relevant data available.

Sources:
(1) Website of the National Council of Sustainable Development. Phnom Penh. https://ncsd.moe.gov.kh/dcc/program/cambodia-climate-change-alliance-ccca
(2) Cambodia's Second National Communication Submitted Under the United Nations Framework on Climate Change. The National Council on Sustainable Development. Ministry of Environment, Royal Government of Cambodia. Phnom Penh. http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/khmnc2.pdf. 
(3) National GHG Emissions Inventory Report. Ministry of Environment, General Department of Administration for Nature Conservation and Protection. Phnom Penh. June 2019. https://unfccc.int/documents/232019

evidence.title: Cambodia's Second National Communication to UNFCCC

indicators.justification:
Basic company information is available in Cambodia[1]. However, the accuracy of the information in the Ministry of Commerce's Business Register has been called into question. According to the 2017 FATF Mutual Evaluation Report of Cambodia, over 50% of legal persons failed to file their annual declaration by the due date, but no sanctions were applied[2]. In addition, international NGO Global Witness (GW) has noted that official data on company ownership in Cambodia was originally openly available, but content regularly changed and also has now been completely removed.[3] 
Sources:
(1) Ministry of Commerce Online Business Register: https://www.businessregistration.moc.gov.kh 
(2) Anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing measures Cambodia - Mutual Evaluation Report. The Asia/Pacific Group of Money laundering. Bangkok. 2017. https://www.fatf-gafi.org/media/fatf/documents/reports/mer-fsrb/Cambodia%20MER%202017%20-%20published%20version.pdf
(3) Global Witness. 2016. Hostile Takeover. https://www.globalwitness.org/en/reports/hostile-takeover/

evidence.title: Ministry of Commerce Online Business Registration

indicators.justification:
There is no realtime data available. Hospitals in Cambodia publish only general information about their capacity/facilities except for Kantha Bopha Children's Hospital, where detailed information can be found in its annual reports. Important data such as the number of ICU beds and oxygen cylinders in public/private hospitals are not publicly available. A number of reports are publicly available, which contain assessments of general capacity constraints in the health sector. ODC has also published a dataset about the names and locations of hospitals/clinics reserved for Covid-19 patients but there is no information about facilities/capacities.
Sources:
(1) Calmette Hospital. Phnom Penh. https://www.calmette.gov.kh
(2) Kantha Bopha Children's Hospital. Phnom Penh. https://www.beat-richner.ch
(3) Ministry of Health, Cambodia. Phnom Penh. http://moh.gov.kh/category/announcements/?lang=en
(4) Open Development Cambodia. Phnom Penh. https://opendevelopmentcambodia.net/topics/health-care-policy-and-administration/ & https://data.opendevelopmentmekong.net/en/dataset/reserved-hospitals-for-covid-19-by-capital-provinces-in-cambodia

evidence.title: Kantha Bopha Children's Hospital, Phnom Penh

indicators.justification:
The government does not release land data, but it is available from international sources, specifically those that utilize open access satellite data.

Thus, information on most types of land use in Cambodia is available on various NGO websites. Comprehensive information on Cambodia's land and mining concessions, as well as forest cover, is available on Open Development Cambodia (1) as well as the Global Forest Watch website (2) via the Open Development Cambodia website and Licadho. INGOs also generally publish flat land use maps used in reports and in some cases on their websites, however they are mostly digitized in inaccessible formats and not downloadable.

Sources:
(1) Open Development Cambodia. https://opendevelopmentcambodia.net/profiles/economic-land-concessions?map_id=elc_od_298
(2) Global Forest Watch website. https://data.globalforestwatch.org/documents/gfw::cambodia-land-concessions/about

indicators.justification:
Some land tenure information has been made available openly, but not by the government. It covers the land areas set aside for social land concessions, economic land concessions, mining concessions and communal land titling. However, it is not representative of the entire country's tenure data - specifically, smallholder land titles which are non-existent in a formalised, publicly available cadastral database. There is no publicly available information on land allocated to individual persons.

Land tenure information is made available by Open Development Mekong (Cambodia).

indicators.justification:
Lobbyists are not defined as such in Cambodia. Attempting to lobby a public official for obtaining services or gaining unfair advantages is considered a punishable offence under Article 606 (Active Trading in Influence) of the Criminal Code and prosecuted under the Law on Anti-Corruption. There is no lobby register in Cambodia and the results of corruption investigations are highly confidential. 
Sources:
(1) Cambodia's Law on Anti-Corruption. http://www.acu.gov.kh/en_sub_index.php?4a8a08f09d37b73795649038408b5f33=2&03c7c0ace395d80182db07ae2c30f034=10&9e3669d19b675bd57058fd4664205d2a=6
(2) Cambodia's Criminal Code. https://www.ajne.org/sites/default/files/resource/laws/7195/criminal-code-cambodia-en-kh.pdf

indicators.justification:
Political finance information is not available as open data. There have always been rumours in Cambodia that business tycoons donate money to the ruling Cambodian People's Party (and perhaps also to the main opposition party), but no verifiable information is publicly available. However, much research has been done by social scientists on Cambodia's patronage politics, and newspapers have published stories about "unethical"/unexplained donations to the government and the ruling party (but not so much anymore because of the current political climate).
Sources:
(1) Abstracts of research studies: See https://www.jstor.org/stable/20071787 & https://www.jstor.org/stable/42704507
(2) Examples of newspaper stories: https://www.phnompenhpost.com/business/commerce-claims-donations-not-political & 
https://english.cambodiadaily.com/news/as-oknha-ranks-grow-honorific-loses-meaning-62057/ & https://www.voacambodia.com/a/ruling-party-new-headquarters-funded-by-members-and-costs-40m-cpp-spokesperson/5409707.html

indicators.justification:
RTI performance information is not available in Cambodia, in part due to the lack of legislation on freedom of information. Sub-national Ombudsmen have begun to receive complaints from citizens but this is a new institution in Cambodia and the perception is that these ombudsmen do nothing beyond what their mandate tells them to do (such as publishing complaints) without clear instructions from the central government. So far, information about citizens' complaints is only published as part of NGO project reporting.
Sources: 
(1) Annual Report 2020. Advocacy and Policy Institute. Phnom Penh. 2020. https://apiinstitute.org/page/our_publications
(2) Ombudsman sub-decree. Ministry of Interior, Royal Government of Cambodia. Phnom Penh. 2019.

indicators.justification:
Data on public consultation is not publicly available in Cambodia. First, "public" consultations in Cambodia refer to meetings between the government/relevant ministry and NGO representatives or representatives from the private sector. Secondly, there is no legal requirement for the government to organize public consultations on draft legislation. Some public consultation proceedings can be traced by comparing newspaper articles [4] as well as NGO critiques of laws. The most high-profile and longest-running public consultations have been those on the Law on NGOs & Associations (LANGO) [1] and the Law on Access to Information (A2I)[2]. NGOs prepared lengthy analyses of the two draft laws and provided many reasoned responses/recommendations to the government during the consultations [3]. Similar types of consultation and analyses of this nature have occurred throughout the years [5],[6],[7].
(1) Analysis of LANGO: Licadho & ADHOC websites. https://www.licadho-cambodia.org/tag/law_on_associations_ngos & https://www.adhoccambodia.org/human-rights-ngos-urge-the-rejection-of-lango/
(2) Analysis of A2I: Article 19 & API websites. https://www.article19.org/resources/cambodia-analysis-of-the-draft-law-on-access-to-information/#:~:text=ARTICLE%2019%20recommends%20that%20the,regulations%20restricting%20access%20to%20information &
https://apiinstitute.org/page/our_publications
(3) ICFL website. Legal analysis of the LANGO. https://www.icnl.org/resources/civic-freedom-monitor/cambodia
(4) Latest news about consultations on the amendment of LANGO. https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50665345/draft-lango-amendments-on-the-table/ &
https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/ministry-consult-civil-society-changes-lango

indicators.justification:
There is only scant evidence of the Cambodian government's active support for data reuse. It is limited to the National Institute of Statistic's stated intention to improve the availability and quality of the data to be used by policy decision-makers, citizens, academics and civil society through the implementation of its strategic plan 2019-2023. The Plan's objectives are internal capacity strengthening, training of government officials and advocacy and public awareness-raising of the importance of statistics. No evidence of the latter can be found on the website and Facebook page of the National Institute.
Sources:
(1) The National Institute of Statistics. 2019. National Strategy for the Development of Statistics 2019-2023. http://www.nis.gov.kh/index.php/km/2-uncategorised/84-national-strategy-for-the-development-of-statistics
(2) Website of the National Institute of Statistics. http://www.nis.gov.kh/index.php/km/

indicators.justification:
There is some evidence of the Cambodian government providing training to develop civil servants' data literacy and data skills, although it is not widespread - except for training in operating the Financial Management Information System provided by the Ministry of Economy and Finance to key finance staff at both the national and the sub-national level. (1)(2)(3)

Pursuant to the Statistics Law (4) the NIS has jurisdiction to coordinate statistical development activities, including trainings. However, the NSDS 2019-2023 (5) is the first statistical development strategy. Indeed, the strategy itself (at p17) notes that "the RGC has not yet focused on statistical development as an important national objective that could be better reflected in the NSDP and national budget, especially with the implementation of the global agenda on sustainable development now under way".
Sources:
(1) The National Institute of Statistics. 2019. The National Strategy for the Development of Statistics 2019-2023. Royal Government of Cambodia. http://www.nis.gov.kh/index.php/km/2-uncategorised/84-national-strategy-for-the-development-of-statistics

indicators.justification:
At present, Cambodia does not have a comprehensive framework for data management and publication. As a result, the websites of government ministries/bodies number about 60, which have all been developed independently without reference to standards for user interface, technical platform or security. The National Institute of Statistics has done piecemeal training of officials in some ministries. Also, the Cambodian government has plans to install a portal where all ministries can display their services and develop a framework for identifying data to serve the public interest, including creating a civil registration system based on personal code numbers. Five government bodies launched the first joint online public service via a Local Data Exchange Platform in June 2020.
Sources:
(1) The World Bank. 2018. Benefiting from the Digitial Economy: Cambodia Policy Note.   https://documents.worldbank.org/en/publication/documents-reports/documentdetail/100841543598854492/benefiting-from-the-digital-economy-cambodia-policy-note
(2) National Institute of Statistics. 2019. National Strategy for the Development of Statistics 2019-2023. Royal Government of Cambodia. http://www.nis.gov.kh/index.php/km/2-uncategorised/84-national-strategy-for-the-development-of-statistics
(3) Phnom Penh Post. January 27, 2021. Ministry of Interior Working on Privacy Protections of Data. https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/ministry-interior-working-privacy-protections-data
(4) Royal Government of Cambodia. 2017. National Strategic Plan for Identification 2017-2026. https://getinthepicture.org/resource/cambodia-national-strategic-plan-identification-2017-2026#:~:text=The%20National%20Strategic%20Plan%20aims,population%20identification%20system%20(IPIS).
(5) Khmer Times. January 21, 2021. Cambodia Goes Digital: Delivering Online Public Services via a Local Data Exchange Platform. https://www.khmertimeskh.com/50805693/cambodia-goes-digital-delivering-online-public-services-via-a-local-data-exchange-platform/

indicators.justification:
There is currently no legal framework for sharing sensitive, proprietary or otherwise non-open data in Cambodia. However, the draft Access to Information Law will provide a more robust framework for sharing sensitive government data with the public in the future. It specifies both which information public institutions may refuse to release and how confidential information may be provided. The only example located of data considered sensitive that have been publicly released is the recent disclosure of names and addresses of Covid-19 infected individuals (made possible by the recent promulgation of a law to prevent the spread of the coronavirus). The draft cybercrime law and the recently adopted sub-decree on a National Internet Gateway are seen by human rights organisations as a veiled attempt by the Cambodian government to restrict freedom of expression rather than a sincere effort to control the spread of harmful information via the internet.
(1) Ministry of Information. 2020. Draft Law on Access to Information. Royal Government of Cambodia.
(2) Human Rights Watch. 2020. Cambodia: Scrap the Draft Cybercrime Law. https://www.hrw.org/news/2020/11/13/cambodia-scrap-draft-cybercrime-law
(3) VDB Loi Cambodia. 2021. Covid-19 in Cambodia: What are the Consequences of Violating the Covid Law? https://www.vdb-loi.com/kh_publications/covid-19-in-cambodia-what-are-the-consequences-of-violating-the-covid-law/

evidence.title: HRW criticism of draft law and sub-decree

The framework covers data sharing within the private sector.
The framework explicitly focuses on artificial intelligence uses of data.

indicators.justification: At present the only relevant law to personal data protection is the E-Commerce Law. Cambodia's Ministry of Interior announced on 26 January 2021 that its lawyers and data specialists had met to discuss an initial draft of a sub-decree consisting of six chapters and 16 articles on the management, use, privacy and security of data collected by the government that can potentially be used to identify individuals (see https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/ministry-interior-working-privacy-protections-data). There is no information on when the drafting process will be completed. Cambodia is also working on reviewing and updating its draft cybercrime law, which contains specific data protection clauses that address preservation of data during criminal investigations, search and seizure of computer data for use as evidence, and potential safeguards for suspects to prevent data privacy abuses. Suggested fines and/or terms of imprisonment have been outlined in the Draft Law for potential cybercrime offences, which include accessing a computer system without a legal right and engaging in data espionage, illegal interception of non-public computer transmissions, and data interference, among others. The draft cybercrime law, originally drafted in 2016, is still pending final approval. In mid-2019, the Cambodian government announced that it was reviewing the draft law to ensure its consistency with current laws and to better outline potential punishments for offenses of it. A third draft was allegedly completed in mid-2020, but none of the drafts have been shared with the public or consulted with civil society organisations or local or international experts. Human Rights Watch, which has obtained a copy of the latest draft, alleges that the law if adopted in its current version will infringe on privacy rights and free speech online and should be scrapped (see https://www.hrw.org/news/2020/11/13/cambodia-scrap-draft-cybercrime-law).

indicators.justification:
Cambodia still does not have an overarching legal framework for the generation and publication of government data. The adoption of an Access to Information Law is still pending. Although the draft law establishes the principle of "maximum disclosure" in government bodies at both national and sub-national levels, it has been criticized for its many ambiguous provisions and unclear definitions and omitting vital components of exemplary access to information legislation. According to OECD, Cambodia has one of the lowest scores in the South-East Asia Open-Useful-Reuseable Government Data Index. Despite the lack of a legal framework, some NGOs manage to collect and publish government data on various topics - foremost among these NGOs is Open Development Cambodia. Also, the Cambodian government has launched a series of initiatives to reform how government bodies provide public services and organize and store data. These e-government initiatives will also make it easier for citizens to access (some) government data. In other words, there seems to be a discrepancy between the Cambodian government's clear intentions to make the provision of public services more efficient through increased use of ICT and the vague definitions of the draft law on access to information that cast doubt on its commitment to promoting the reuse of public data.
(1) Ministry of Information. 2020. Draft Law on Access to Information. Royal Government of Cambodia.
(2) OECD. 2019. Government at a Glance - Country Fact Sheet Cambodia.
(3) Open Development Cambodia. https://opendevelopmentcambodia.net/
(4) Konrad Adenauer Stiftung. 2019. Digital Government to Business Services in Cambodia: Overview and Challenges. https://www.kas.de/en/web/kambodscha/single-title/-/content/digital-government-to-business-services-in-cambodia-overview-and-challenges
(5) Cambodia Development Center. 2021. E-Government in Cambodia: Challenges and Practical Paths to Achieve a Functional E-Government.

indicators.justification:
The Law on Public Finance does not require government bodies to publish any budget information. However, the Cambodian government has committed itself to increase budget transparency (as part of the implementation of Phase 3 of its Public Financial Management Reform Program and improved its score in the Open Budget Survey from 8 (in 2015) to 32 (in 2019) by publishing more information about its revenue and expenditure. Sub-national legislation requires that provinces, municipalities, districts and municipalities at annual public forums provide citizens with information about the allocation of development funds and the implementation of development plans, which presumably include the expenditure, although the language of the relevant sections is a bit vague (thus taking the form of guidance rather than a requirement). 
Sources:
(1) International Budget Partnership. Open Budget Survey Cambodia 2019. https://www.internationalbudget.org/open-budget-survey/country-results/2019/cambodia
(2) Public Financial Management Reform Programme. Ministry of Economy and Finance, Royal Government of Cambodia. https://www.pfm.gov.kh/index.php/en/about-pfm-en
(3) Commune Administration Law. Cambodia. http://huskyandpartners.com/images///Law%20Library/Administrative%20Law/20180825-Law%20on%20Commune-Sangkat%20Administrative%20Management_2001_En.pdf
(4) Law on the Administrative Management of Capital, Provinces, Municipalities and Districts. Cambodia. https://seaknowledgebank.net/e-library/cambodia-law-administrative-management-capital-provinces-municipalities-districts

indicators.justification:
Cambodia's Law on Anti-Corruption requires all public servants to declare all their assets and liabilities every two years and the forms are collected by the government's Anti-Corruption Unit (see https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/acu-receives-20k-asset-declarations). However, the law's article 20 specifies that the declarations are highly confidential and can only be opened at the discretion of the ACU's chairperson. This happens extremely rarely (see https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/acu-unseal-sokhas-asset-records).
Source:
(1) Law on Anti-Corruption. The Anti-Corruption Unit website: http://www.acu.gov.kh/en_sub_index.php?4a8a08f09d37b73795649038408b5f33=2&03c7c0ace395d80182db07ae2c30f034=10&9e3669d19b675bd57058fd4664205d2a=6

indicators.justification:
Cambodia's 1997 Law on Political Parties requires every party to submit a yearly financial report to the Ministry of Economy and Finance that must include the party's bank statements, lists of expenditures, and a narrative report of the party's principal activities. Although parties are required to submit a record of expenditures, they are not required to publicly declare party assets. The MEF is responsible for reviewing these reports to ensure that there is no conflict with the constitution. There are no provisions concerning public disclosure of the review findings. The draft Access to Information Law does not cover political finance either. In other words, there is no framework in Cambodia for the collection and publication of data on political campaigns and party finance.
Sources:
(1) Cambodia's 1997 Law on Political Parties. https://www.refworld.org/docid/3ae6b51414.html
(2) Cambodia's draft Access to Information Law.

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of campaigning activities of parties, candidates, and third parties.

responses.response_text: The framework does not require the disclosure, public or otherwise, of a donor's identity.
responses.subquestion_text: The framework requires donors' identities be made public.
The framework requires collecting specific information on financial contributions.
The framework requires collecting specific information on assets and liabilities.
The framework requires collecting specific information on income and spending.
The framework requires collecting specific information on in-kind and non-financial support.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The framework requires regular updates, including updates in conjunction with campaigns and defined campaign schedules.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

indicators.justification:
Although not prescribed by law, the Cambodian government organises stakeholder consultations with the purpose of discussing draft laws and collecting stakeholder views and recommendations, e.g. on private sector issues (through the regularly held Government-Private Sector Forum), on environmental issues (the draft Environmental Impact Assessment Law), on the Law on NGOs and Associations) and on the draft Access to Information Law (the consultation process took more than two years with input from civil society and youth groups). In other words: It is a practice or policy (within some areas of government), not a legal requirement. Public consultations on the implementation of government policies/development plans are regularly held at the sub-national level, where it is a formal requirement according to the law on sub-national (provincial, district and commune) administrations. Legislation has also been developed for how to organize public consultations at the sub-national level (see https://www.pic.org.kh/index.php/en/events-eng/9-seminar-public-consultation-guidelines.html). According to the Ministry of Environment Prakas No. 021 on Classification of Environmental Impact Assessment for Development Project, all proposals of development projects of private individuals or private companies, joint-venture companies, public companies or government ministries/agencies must conduct an EIA, including consultation with Project Affected Persons. The MoE has published a list of EIAs conducted (see https://opendevelopmentcambodia.net/profiles/environmental-impacts-assessments/), but no data from these consultations are publicly available. The draft Access to Information Law does not cover civic participation in the legislative process, i.e. the right to be heard.
Sources:
(1) Application of the Cambodian Constitution -
Assessment of Constitutional Law-Making Process and the Right to Public Participation. Journal of South-East Asian Human Rights. University of Jemper in Jakarta, Indonesia. 2019. https://jurnal.unej.ac.id/index.php/JSEAHR/article/view/8406
(2) Government-Private Sector Forum in Cambodia. Cambodian Federation of Employers and Business Associations Website. https://www.camfeba.com/representative.html & https://pressocm.gov.kh/en/archives/50962
(3) Cambodia Holds Public Consultations for Draft Environmental Impact Assessment Law. Mekong-US Partnership. Washington D.C, US. 2014. https://mekonguspartnership.org/2014/10/17/cambodia-holds-public-consultations-for-draft-environmental-impact-assessment-law/
(4) Working Towards an Access to Information Law in Cambodia: Bridging the Government and Citizens for Participatory Law-making. UNESCO Cambodia. Phnom Penh. 2014. https://en.unesco.org/partnerships/foe/working-towards-access-to-info-in-cambodia

indicators.justification:
There are currently no laws, policies, or regulations in Cambodia that provide a basis for the collection and publication of data on the processes of the right to information/freedom of information. However, the draft Access to Information Law, which is in its final stages before its adoption but has been delayed due to the Covid-19 pandemic, contains two articles alluding to this right.
Sources: 
(1) Draft Access to Information Law in Cambodia.
(2) Introduction to Access to Information in Cambodia. Advocacy and Policy Institute. Phnom Penh. 2010. http://ticambodia.org/library/wp-content/files_mf/1452238572a2ienglish.pdf

indicators.justification:
There is no evidence of political integrity data being used to identify, expose, or highlight failures of government since this data is not openly available. International and national NGOs have used some political integrity information to highlight the failures of the Cambodian government in the area of human rights and good governance, but arguably with little effect. Following the ban on the main opposition party in late 2017, a culture of self-censorship has taken root in the media sector in the country, which has significantly limited the publication of newspaper articles on controversial topics. On the other hand, pressure from the private sector, including members of the European Chamber of Commerce in Cambodia, has had a positive effect on trade facilitation.
Sources: 
(1) Licadho research on Economic Land Concessions. https://www.licadho-cambodia.org/land_concessions/
(2) Cooperation Committee for Cambodia statement on the LANGO. https://www.ccc-cambodia.org/en/media-center/latest-news/cso-leaders-meetingroadmap-and-post-lango-consultation
(3) Corruption Perceptions in Cambodian SMEs. Transparency International Cambodia. Phnom Penh. 2015.
https://www.ticambodia.org/download/report-corruption-perceptions-cambodia-smes/
(4) Business Integrity Country Assessment Report. Transparency International Cambodia. Phnom Penh. 2017. http://www.ticambodia.org/bica2017/

indicators.justification:
Public procurement data is not publicly available, so there are no examples of this such data being used to improve procurement practices. Outside of this there have been a few isolated examples of public procurement information (or rather practices) being analyzed/ used to improve procurement practices - albeit in a very general sense and mainly through NGO advocacy.

The specific advocacy conducted by NGO's isn't really able to utilize open public procurement data because it doesn't adhere to any standards and is not necessarily open - there is limited release of contract data nor beneficial ownership data.

Sources:
(1) Business Integrity Assessment Report Cambodia. Phnom Penh. 2017. http://www.ticambodia.org/bica2017/
(2) NGO Forum Budget Working Group.   https://www.unescap.org/sites/default/files/Session%202%20BWG%20Budget%20working%20group.pdf).
(3) The Global Fund scandal. https://www.theglobalfund.org/media/2774/oig_gfoig13050investigationcambodia_report_en.pdf &
https://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/fraud-malaria-centre-global-fund-report-uncovers-systematic-double-billing-nepotism & https://www.aidspan.org/en/c/article/2105 & https://aidspan.org/en/c/article/4126
